doc.description: Daniel Tammet has linguistic, numerical and visual synesthesia -- meaning that his perception of words, numbers and colors are woven together into a new way of perceiving and understanding the world. The author of "Born on a Blue Day," Tammet shares his art and his passion for languages in this glimpse into his beautiful mind.
doc.title: Daniel Tammet: Different ways of knowing
doc.seg: i'm as a font, or more precisely, a high-functioning autistic savant
it's a rare condition
and rarer still when accompanied, as in my case, by self-awareness and a mastery of language
very often when i meet someone and they've learned is about me, there's a certain kind of awkwardness
i can see it in their lives
they want to ask me something
and in the end, quite often, the urge stronger than they are and they blurted out, if i give you my date of birth, can it's an order of the week i was born on
well they mention cube roots all asked me to recite a long number or long text
i hope you'll forgive me, if i don't perform a kind of one-man savant show for you today
i i'm going to talk instead about something far more interesting than these of first full cube roots, a little deeper and a lot closer, to my mind, and work
i want to talk to you briefly about perception

when he was my team that plays in the short story step would make his name, anton chekhov kept a notebook in which he noted down his observations of the world around him, little details that other people seem to miss
every time i read chekhov and his unique vision of human life, i'm reminded of why i too became a light
in my books, i explore nature of perception and how different kinds of perceiving create different kinds of knowing and understanding
here are three questions drawn from my work
i love it and try to figure them out, and going to ask you to consider for a moment the intuitions and the gut instincts they're going through your head and your heart as you look at them
for example the calculation
can you feel well and the number line the solution is likely to fall?
well look at the four and work and the sounds
can you get a sense of the range of meanings but it's pointing you towards?
and in terms of the line of poetry, why does the poet use the word hare laugh and in love it?
i'm asking you to do this because i believe that our personal perceptions, you see, like the heart of how we acquire knowledge
aesthetic judgments, rather than abstract reasoning, guide and shape the process by which we all come to know what we know
i'm an extreme example of this
my worlds of words and numbers lair with color, emotion and personality
as kwan said, it's a condition that scientists call soonest easier, when usual course talk between the fences
here are the numbers one to twelve as i see them, every number with its own shape and character
one is a flash of light light
six is a tiny and very sad black hole
the sketches i'm black and white it, but in my mind they have come to this
three is going
four is blue
five is yellow
i paint as well
and here is one of my paintings
it's a multiplication of two prime numbers
three-dimensional shapes and the space they create in the middle creates a new shape, the answer to the sum
what about bigger numbers
well you can't get much bigger than empowering, the mathematical constant
it's an infinite number, literally goes on forever
in this painting but i made of the first twenty decimals of pi, i take the covers and the emotions and the textures and i paula more together into a kind of rolling numerical landscape
but it's not only numbers that i see in countries
words too, for me, have colors and emotions and textures
and this is an opening phrase from the novel lolita
and nabokov was himself soon is static
and you can see here how my perception of the sound l helps the alliteration to jump right out
another example, a little bit more mathematical
when i wonder if some of you will notice the construction of the sentence from the great gatsby
there is a procession of syllables, wheat, one. prairies, two. lost swede towns, three, one, two, three
and this effect is very pleasant on the mind, and it helps the sentence to feel like it
let's go back to the questions i posed your moments ago
sixty four multiplied by seventy five
it so if you played chess, your know that sixty four is a square number, and that's why just forwards, eight by eight, have sixty four squares
so that gives us a form that we can picture, we can perceive
about seventy five
well it's a hundred, we think of a hundred as of being a like a square, seventy five would look like this
so what we need to do now is put those two pictures together in our mind, something like this
sixty four become sixty four hundred
and in the light hand corner, you don't have to calculate anything
full across, four up and down, at sixteen
so what the sum is actually asking you to do is sixteen, sixteen, sixteen
that's a lot easier than the way that the school taught you to do math, some show
it's sixteen, sixteen, sixteen, forty eight, forty eight hundred, four thousand eight hundred, the answer to the sum
easy when you know how
the second question was an icelandic word
i'm assuming are not many people here who speak icelandic
so let me now over choices down to two
is it a happy word was sad word?
what you say?
market
some people say it's happy
most people, a majority of people say sad
and it actually means out
why do, statistically, a majority of people say that a word is sad, in this case, heavy in other cases?
in my theory language evolves in such a way that sounds match, correspond with the subjective, with the personal intuitive experience of the listener
let's have a look at the the third question
it's a line from a poem by john keeps
words, like numbers, express fundamental relationships between objects and events and forces that constitute our world
it stands to reason that we, existing in this well it, should be in the course of our lives absorb intuitively those relationships
some poets, like other artists, play with those intuitive understandings
in the case of hare, it's an ambiguous sound in english
you can also mean the five a quote from ahead
and if we think of that, we put the picture up, the five was represent vulnerability
there you would to the slightest movement or motion or emotion
so what you have is an atmosphere of vulnerability intention
the hare itself the animal, not a cat, litter dog, hair, why hair?
because think of the picture, not a word, the picture
the overlong ears, the over large feet, helps us to picture, to feel intuitively, what it means to limp and to tremble
so in these few minutes, i hope i've been able to share a little bit of my vision of things, and to show you that words can have colors and emotions, numbers, shapes and personalities
the world is richer, vaster than it too often seems to be
i hope that i've given you desire to learn to see the world with new eyes
thank you

doc.description: How do you stage an international art show with work from 100 different artists? If you're Shea Hembrey, you invent all of the artists and artwork yourself -- from large-scale outdoor installations to tiny paintings drawn with a single-haired brush. Watch this funny, mind-bending talk to see the explosion of creativity and diversity of skills a single artist is capable of.
doc.title: Shea Hembrey: How I became 100 artists
doc.seg: i'm going to play artist with a bit of an unexpected background
i was in my twenties before i ever which an art museum
i grew up in the middle of nowhere on a dirt road in rural arkansas, an hour from the nearest movie theater
and i think it was a great place to grow up as an artist, because i grew up around quirky, colorful characters who are great at making with their hands
and my childhood is more hick than i could ever possibly relate to you, and also a more intellectual than you would ever expect
for instance, me and my sister, we were little, we would compete to see who could eat the most squirrel brains
but it on the other side of that though, we are we are big readers in our house
and if the TV was on we're watching a documentary
and my dad is the most voracious reader i know
you can read a novel or two a day
but when i was little, i remember, he would kill flies in our house with my BB gun
and what was so amazing to me about that, what he would be in his recliner, would holler for me to fetch that BB gun, and i'd go get it
and what was amazing to me, was a bullet was pretty kickass, he was killing a fly in the house with a gun, but what was so amazing to me was that he knew just enough how pump
and he could shoot it for you know like two rooms away and not damage what was on, because he knew how to pump it just enough to kill the fly and not damage what it was landed on
so i should talk about or
but that will be here all day with my childhood stories
i love contemporary art, but i'm also doing really frustrated with the contemporary art world and the contemporary art scene
a few years ago, i spent months in europe to see the major international art exhibitions that no have the pulse of what is supposed to be going on in the art world
and i was struck by going to so many, one after the other, kind of with some clarity of what it was that i was longing for
i mean i'm going for several things i wasn't getting, or not getting enough love
but to the main things, one of that, i was longing for more work that was appealing to a broad public, that was accessible
and the second thing that i was going for was more exquisite craftsmanship and technique
so i i started thinking and listing what all it was that i thought would make a perfect biennial
so i decided, i'm going to start my own biennial
i'm going to organize and direct it and get it going in the world
so i thought, okay, i have to have some criteria of how to choose work
so amongst all the country had, this kind of two main things
one of them, i call my mama's test
and what that is is i imagine explaining a work of art to my grandmother in five minutes
and if i can explain it five minutes, then it's it's too obtuse or are as a trick and it has been refined enough yet
it needs to be worked on intelligence speak fluently
and then my other second set of rules, i hate to say rules because it's are caught, my criteria would be the three ages, which is a head, heart and hands
and great art would have hit, it would have interesting intellectual ideas and concepts
it would have heart in that it would have passionate heart and soul
and it would have hand in that it would be greatly crafted
so i started thinking about poker hand this biennial, how i'm going to show how my going to travel the world and find these artists
and then i realized one day, that there's an easier solution to this
i'm just going to make the whole thing myself
and so this is what i did
i i i thought, okay biennial needs artists
number did in international biennial, i need artists from all around the world
so what i did was i invented a hundred artists from around the world
i figured out their bios, their passions in life and their art styles, and i started making their work
and so i thought well, this is kind of project that i did my whole life doing
so i decided, i'm going to make this a real biennial
it's only two years of studio work
and i'm going to create this in two years
in i have
so i i should i should start to talk about these guys
well the range is it's quite a bit
and i'm such a technician, so i love this project, getting to play with all the techniques
so for example, in realist paintings, ranges from like this, which is kind of old masters style, to really realistic still-life, to this type of painting where i'm painting with a single hair
and then at the other end, there's performance and short sounds and endorsed installations like this indoor installations and this one, and other installations like this one and this one
a nice image, i'm making all these things
this is isn't publish opt
i'm like under the river with those fish
so now let me introduce some of my fictional artists do you
this is now reynolds
now i was interested in agricultural processes, and her work is based in these practices
this piece, which is called flipped earth, she was interested in taking the sky and using it to cleanse barren ground
and by taking giant mirrors, in here she's taking giant mirrors and then pulling them into the dirt
and the great this is twenty two feet long
what i loved about her work is, when i walk around it in and look and look down into the sky, you know looking down to watch the sky, and it folded in a new way
and probably the best part of this piece is at dusk and dawn when mike that the twilight which is falling on the ground stark, but this the light above bright above
and so you're standing there anything else to start, that there's this portal that you want to jump in
and this piece was great. this is in my parents' backyard in arkansas
and i love to dig a hole
so this piece was great fine, has it was two days of digging and softer

and in her most recent project, it's called weather i made
and she's making weather on her body's scale

and so this is five foot, five inches of frost that she left behind
the sun rises, and it melts away

so the next artist, this is a group of japanese artists, a collective of japanese artists, in their own and in tokyo

and they needed funding for it, so they decided to come up with some interesting fundraising projects
one of these is scratch-off masterpieces
and so so what they're doing, each of these artists on a nine by seven inch card, which they sell for ten bucks, they drew original works of art
and you buy one, and maybe you get a real peace and maybe not

those first two are tortured to make a jackpot winners years before and after their win

he draws sticks real the
which is one of the best coverage ever

and what he does is, he spends a week at a time with the family
any these shows up on the shows up on their porch, their doorstep, with was a toothbrush and pajamas, and he's ready to spend a week with them
and using only what's present, he goes in and makes a little abode studio to work out of

any digs through everything they have, and he finds materials to make war

and so she came up with creating these pocket-sized artworks that are portraits of the person that would carry them

and they're interested in creating culture, just tradition
so what they do is they move into an area and try to establish a new tradition and a small geographic area
so this is in eastern tennessee, and what they decided was that you know we need a positive tradition that goes with death
so they came up with big gigs
and it did did, i did you is where, for a milestone anniversary or birthday, you are and you get all your friends and family together and you dance on where you're going to be buried
and we we got a lot of it is a millimeter thick is this
i talked my family into doing this, all that and what i was doing
like dress if you know, we're going to go do some work

he is interested in how we see as an animal, how we are interested in mimicry and camouflage
you know we look down a dark alley or jungle path, trying to make out a face or a preacher

so he pairs these up

and he pairs these out with paintings
like this is a painting of a stake in a box

doc.description: At TED's Full Spectrum Auditions, comedian Joshua Walters, who's bipolar, walks the line between mental illness and mental "skillness." In this funny, thought-provoking talk, he asks: What's the right balance between medicating craziness away and riding the manic edge of creativity and drive?
doc.title: Joshua Walters: On being just crazy enough
doc.seg: my name is joshua walters
i'm a performer
in the end but the beginning to the end of the world and the and the end of the day i was only performer, i'm also diagnosed bipolar
reframe that as a positive, because the crazier i get onstage, the more entertaining i become
when i was sixteen in san francisco, have my breakthrough manic episode in which i thought i was jesus christ
maybe you thought that was a no scary, but actually there's no matter drugs you can take the can get you as high as if you think you're jesus christ
i was sent to a place, psych ward and in the psych ward, everyone is doing their own one-man show
there's an audience like this to justify their rehearsal time
the just practising
one day they'll get here
now when i got out, i was diagnosed and i was given medications by a psychiatrist
moving in kenya as well we give you some, work well we give you some merger this summer zyprexa
thank you
at least that's what it says in my pen
some of you are in the field i can see
i can feel your noise
the first half of high school was the struggle of the manic episode, in the second half was the over medications of these drugs, when i was sleeping through high school
the second half was just one big nap, pretty much, in class
when i got out i had a choice
i could either deny my mental illness or embrace my mental stillness
there's a movement going on right now to reframe mental illness as a positive, at least the hype manic edge part of it
now if you don't know what hype mania is, it's like an engine that's out of control, maybe a ferrari engine with no breaks
many of the speakers here, many of you in the audience, have that creative edge, if you know what i'm talking about
you driven to do something that everyone has told you is impossible
is a book, john gardner
john gartner wrote this book called the hype manic edge in which christopher columbus and ted turner and steve jobs and all these business minds have this edge to compete

a different book was written not too long ago in the mid nineties called a called touch with fire by kay redfield jamison, in which it was that that in a creative sense, in which motes art and they told that and then go all had this manic depression that they were suffering with
some them committed suicide
so it wasn't all the good side of the illness
now recently there's been development in this field
and there was a article written in the new york times, september two thousand ten, the stated, it just manic enough

just be manic enough in which investors we're looking for entrepreneurs or worse they had this kind of spectrum, you know what i'm talking about not maybe full bipolar, but they're in the bipolar spectrum, when one side, maybe you think you're jesus, and on the other side maybe they just make you a lot of money
your call. your car
everyone's somewhere in the middle
everyone's somewhere in the middle
so maybe, you know, there's no such thing as crazy, and being diagnosed with a mental illness doesn't mean you're crazy
maybe it just means you're more sensitive to what most people can't see or feel
maybe no one's really crazy
everyone is just a little bit mad
how much depends on where you fall in the spectrum
how much depends on how lucky you are
thank you

doc.description: When Dave deBronkart learned he had a rare and terminal cancer, he turned to a group of fellow patients online -- and found the medical treatment that saved his life. Now he calls on all patients to talk with one another, know their own health data, and make health care better one e-Patient at a time.
doc.title: Dave deBronkart: Meet e-Patient Dave
doc.seg: it's amazing thing that we're here to talk about the year of patients rising
you heard stories earlier today about patients who are taking control of their cases, patients who are saying, you know what, i know what the odds are, but i'm going to go look for more information
i'm going to define what the terms of my success are
i'm gonna be sharing with you how four years ago i almost died, found out i was, in fact, already almost dead
and what i been found out about what's called the e patient movement, i'll explain what that term means
i have been blogging under the name patient dave, and when i discovered this, i just renamed myself he patient days

regarding the word patient, when i first started a few years ago getting involved in health care and attending meetings as just a casual observer, i noticed that people would talk about patients as if it was somebody who's not in the room here, somebody out there
some of our talks today, we still act like that
but i'm here to tell you, patient is not a third-person word
you, yourself, will find yourself in a hospital bed, or your mother, your child, their heads nodding, people who say, yes, i know exactly what you mean
so when you win you hear what i'm going to talk about here today, first of all, i want to say that i'm here on behalf of all the patients that i've ever met, all the ones i haven't met
this is about letting patients play a more active role in helping health care, in fixing health care
one of the senior doctors in my hospital, charlie saffron, and his colleague, warner slack, have been saying for decades that the most underutilized resource in all of health care is the patient
they've been saying that since the nineteen seventies
that would step back in history
this is from july, nineteen sixty nine
i was a freshman in college, and this was when we first landed on the moon
it was the first time we've ever seen from another surface, that's the place where you and i are right now, where we live
the world was changing
there is about to change in ways that nobody could foresee
a few weeks later, woodstock happened
three days of fun and music
here, just for historical authenticity, is a picture of me in that year
i have bite the other way, the hair blue eyes, it was really something
that fall of nineteen sixty nine, the whole earth catalog came out
it was a hippie journal of self-sufficiency
we think of hippies as being just hedonists, but there's a very strong component, i was in that movement, a very strong component of being responsible for yourself
this book's title's subtitle is, access to tools
and he talked about how to build your own house, how to grow your own food, all kinds of things
in the nineteen eighties, this young doctor, tom ferguson, was the medical editor of the whole earth catalog
and he saw that the great majority of what we do in medicine health care is taking care of ourselves
in fact, he said was seventy to eighty percent of our how we actually take care of our bodies
well try he also saw that when health care turns to medical care because of a more serious disease, the key thing that holds us back is access to information
and when the web came along that changed everything, because not only could we find information, we could find other people like ourselves who could gather, who could bring us information
and he coined this term the patients, equipped, engaged, empowered, enabled
obviously at this stage of life, he was in a somewhat more dignified form that he was back there
now i was an engaged patient long before i ever heard of the term
in two thousand six, i went to my doctor for regular physical, and i said i have a sore shoulder
well, i got an x-ray, and the next morning, you may have noticed, those of you who have had been through medical crisis will understand this
this morning, some of the speakers named the date when they found out about their condition
for me, it was nine AM on january thirty, two thousand seven
i was at the office. my desk was clean. out of the blue partition carpet on the walls
the phone rang and it was my doctor
he said that he said, dave, i called up the x-ray image on the screen the computer at home
he said, his shoulders going to be fine, but they, there's something in your life
if you look in that red oval, that shadow was not supposed to be there
to make a long story short, they said, so you need me to get back in there
he said, you really need to do a CT scan of your trust
the lights in parting i said, is there anything i should do
we said, i think about this one
this is the advice of doctor gives you
just go home and have a glass of wine with your wife
i went in for the cat scan, and turns out there were five of these things in both my lungs
so at that point we knew that it was cancer
we know wasn't lung cancer
that meant it was met has the size from somewhere
the question was where from?
so i went in for an ultrasound
i got to do what many women have, jelly on the belly in the indices
my wife came with me
she's a veterinarian, she's seen lots of ultrasounds
i mean, she knows another dog
but what we saw, this is an MRI image
this is much sharper than an ultrasound would be
what we saw in that to me was that big blob there
and there are actually two of these
one was growing out the front of it already erupted, in latched onto the ball
one was growing out the back, and it attached to the soulless muscle, which is a big muscle in the back that i'd never heard of, it all of a sudden i cared about it
i went home
now i've been googling, i've been online since nineteen eighty nine and compuserve
i went home, and i know you can't read the details here. that's not important
my point is i went to a respected medical website, where in the, because i know how to filter out junk
right i also found my wife online
before i met her, i went through some suboptimal search results
so i did what i looked for quality information
there's so much about trust, what sources of information can we trust?
where does my body end and an invader start?
you know cancer, tomas, something you grow out of your own tissue
how does that happen?
where metal medical ability end and start?
well, so what i read on whether it be, the prognosis is poor for progressing renal cell cancer
almost all patients are incurable
i've been online long enough to know if i don't like the first results i get, to go look for more
and what i found was on other websites, even by the third page of google results, outlook is bleak, prognosis is grim
and i'm thinking, what the heck
i didn't feel sick at all
i mean, i've been getting tired in the evening, but i was fifty six years old
i was slowly losing weight, but for me, that was what the doctor told me that
it was it was really something
this is the diagram of stage four kidney cancer from the drug they eventually got
i totally by coincidence, there's that thing in my life
in the left femur, the left thigh bone, there's another one
i have one. my leg eventually snapped
i think that landed on it, and it broke
there's one in the skull, and then just for good measure, i had these other tumors, including, by the time i treatment started, one was growing out of my tongue
the kidney cancer growing out of my tongue
and what i read was that my median survival was twenty four weeks
this is bad
i was facing the grain
i thought, that's my mother's face can look like on the day of my funeral
i have to sit down with my daughter and say, not be here's the situation
her boyfriend was weather
i said, i don't want you guys to get married prematurely just so you can do it while dad's still alive
so really serious
this if you wonder why patients are motivated and want to help, to think about this
well, my doctor prescribed the patient community, a cordon or, a network of cancer patients, of all amazing things
very quickly they told me, kidney cancer is an uncommon disease
get yourself to a specialist centre
there is no cure, but there's something that sometimes works, it usually doesn't, called high dosage into look good
most hospitals don't offer it, so they won't even tell you it exists
and don't let them give you anything else first
by the way, here are four doctors in your part of the united states who offer it and their phone numbers
how amazing is that
here's the thing
here we are, four years later, you can find a website that gives patients that information
government-approved, american cancer society, but patients know what patients want to now
it's the power of patient networks
this amazing substance, again i i mentioned, where does my body end?
my oncologist and i talk a lot these days, because they try to keep my talks technically accurate
he said, you know, the immune system is good at detecting invaders, now that bacteria coming from outside, but when it's your own tissue that you've grown, it's a whole different effect

and i went through a mental exercise actually, there's i started a patient a support community of my own on a website, and one of my friends, were my relatives actually, said, look, dave, who through this thing?
how are you going to set yourself up as mentally attacking yourself?
so we we went into it
the story of how all that happens is in the book
anyway, this is the way the numbers unfolded
the being me, i put the numbers from my hospital's website from my tumor sizes into a spreadsheet
i don't worry about the numbers
see, that's the immune system
amazing thing, goes to yellow lines are where i got the two doses of into and two months apart
and look at how the tumor sizes plummeted in between
just incredible
who knows what we'll be able to do when we learn to make more use of
and the punch line is that a year and a half later, i was there when this magnificent young woman, my daughter, got married
even when she came down those steps, and it was just her and me for that moment, i was so glad that you didn't have to say to her mother, i wish that i could have been here
and this is what we're doing when we make health care better
now i want to talk briefly about a couple of other patients who are doing everything in their power to improve health care
this is regina holliday, a painter in washington DC, whose husband died of kidney cancer year after my disease
she's painting here a mural of his horrible final weeks in the hospital
one of the things that she discovered was that her husband's medical record in this paper folder was just disorganized

and she thought, you know, if i have a nutrition facts label on the side of a cereal box, why can't there be something that simple telling every new nurse who comes on duty, every new doctor, the basics about my husband's condition?
so she painted this medical facts mural of with the nutrition label, the something like that, and the diagram of him
she that, last year, painted this diagram
she studied health care like me
she came to realize that there were a lot of people who'd written patient advocate books that you just don't hear about it medical conferences
patients are such an underutilized resource
well as it said my introduction, i've gotten somewhat known for saying that patients should have access to their data
and i actually said at one conference a couple years ago, give me my damn data, because you people can be trusted to keep it clean
and here she has our damned data, it's upon, which is starting to break out, starting to break through, the water symbolizes our data
and in fact, i want to do a little something improvisational for you here
there's a guy on twitter that i know, my health IT guy outside boston, and he wrote that he patient rap
and it goes like this
the way my damn data. i want to be in the patient just like they. do me my damn data. because it's not to say that i couldn't go any further
well thank you. that's up the timing
i think about the possibility, why is it that i phones and i had to advance far faster than the health tools that are available to you to help take carrier family?
here's a website, visible body that come, that i stumbled across
my thought, you know, i wonder what my so it's muscle is?
so you can click on things and remove it
and i saw, a heart, that's the kidney in the source muscle
i was rotating it in three d and saying, i understand now
and then i realized it reminded me of google earth, where you can fly to any dress
and i thought, why not take this and connected to my digital scan data and have google earth from my body?
what did will come out with this year?
now there's google body browser
but we see, that it's still generic
it's not my data
but if we can get that they'd have out from behind the dam so software innovators can pounce on it, the way software innovators like to do, who knows what we'll be able to come up with
one final story, this is kelly young, a rheumatoid arthritis patient from florida
this is a live story unfolding just in the last few weeks
our eight patients, as they call themselves, heard her bloggers are a warrior, have a big problem because forty percent of them have no visible symptoms
and that makes it is really hard to tell how the disease is going
in some doctors think, yeah right, you really in pain
well she found, through her online research, in nuclear bone scan that's usually used for cancer, but it can also reveal inflammation
and she saw that if it's a if there is no inflammation and understand a uniform gray
so he took it
and the radiologist report said, no cancer found
let's not ready response to do with it
so she had it read again, she wanted to have it read again, and her doctor fired her
she pulled up the CD
he said, i if you don't want to follow mice instructions, go away
so she pulled up the CD and of the scan images, and look at all those hot spots
end of it is now actively engaged other blogging looking for assistance in getting better care
see, that is an empowered patient, no medical training
we are, you are, the most underused resource in health care
what she was able to do was because she had access to the raw data
how big a deal was this?

well it tends to thousand nine, tim berners-lee himself, inventor of the web, gave a talk where he said the next big thing is not to have your browser go out and find other people's articles about the data, but the raw data
and he got them chanting by the end of the talk, raw data now
raw data now
and i ask you, to three words, please, to improve health care, let patients help

doc.description: Bill Ford is a car guy -- his great-grandfather was Henry Ford, and he grew up inside the massive Ford Motor Co. So when he worries about cars' impact on the environment, and about our growing global gridlock problem, it's worth a listen. His vision for the future of mobility includes "smart roads," even smarter public transport and going green like never before.
doc.title: Bill Ford: A future beyond traffic gridlock
doc.seg: by birth and by choice, i've been involved with the auto industry my entire life, and for the past thirty years, i've worked at ford motor company
it for most of those years, i worried about, coming in to sell more cars and trucks?
but today i worry about, what if all we do is sell more cars and trucks?
what happens when the number of vehicles on the road doubles, triples, or even quadruples
my life is guided by two great passions, and the first is automobiles
i literally grew up with the ford motor company
i thought i was so cool as a little boy when my dad would bring home the latest ford a lincolns and leave it in the driveway
and it i decided about that time, about age ten, that would be really cool if i was a test driver
so i counted go to dinner
they'd sit down, i'd sneak out of the house
i jump behind the wheel and take the new model around the driveway, and was a blast
the net went on for about two years, until, i think there's about twelve, my dad brought home a a lincoln mark three
and it was snowing that day
so in went to dinner
and i stuck out and not be really cool to do doughnuts and maybe even some figure eights in the snow
my dad finished in early that evening
and he was walking to the front hall and out the front door just about the same time i hit some ice and met him at the front door with the car, and almost ended up in the front hall
so can i called my test-driving for a little while
the height really began to love cars then
and my first car was a nineteen seventy five electric green mustang
and even though the color was pretty hideous, i did love the car, and really cemented my love affair with cars it's continued on this day
but cars are really more than a passion of mine. they're quite literally in my blood
my great grandfather was henry ford, and on my mother's side, of my great grandfather was harvey firestone
so when i was born, i guess you could say expectations were kind of high for me
but my great grandfather, henry ford, really believe that the mission of the ford motor company was to make people's lives better and make cars affordable so that everyone could happen
because he believed that, with mobility, comes freedom and progress
and that's a belief that i share
well the great passion is the environment
and as young boy, i used to go up to northern michigan and fish in the rivers that hemingway fished in and then later wrote about

and it really struck me in as the years went by, in a in a very negative way, when i would go to some stream that i'd loved, and was used to walk into this field that was once filled with fireflies, and now head strip mall or about condos on it
and so even at a young age, that really resonated with me
and and the whole notion of environmental preservation, at a very basic level, sunk in with me
as a high school, i started to read authors like throw elderly appalled and edward abbey
a and i really began to develop a deeper appreciation of the natural world
but it never really occurred to me that my love of cars and in trucks would ever be in conflict with nature
and that was true until i got to college

and what i got to college, you can imagine my surprise when i would go to class and a number of my professors would say that ford motor company and my family was kind of everything that was wrong with a lot of our country
they thought that we were more interested, as an industry, in profits, rather than progress, and that we filled the skies with smog, and frankly, we were the enemy
i joined ford after college, after some soul-searching whether not this is really the right thing to do
but i decided that i wanted to go and see if i could affect change there
and as i look back over thirty years ago, i was a little naive to think at that age that i could, but i wanted to
i really discovered that my professors were completely wrong
in fact, when i got back to detroit, my environmental leanings one exactly embraced by those in my own company, and certainly by those in the industry
i it's very interesting conversations, are is you can imagine
there were some are within ford who believed that all this ecological nonsense should just disappear and that i needed to stop hanging out with quote environmental wackos
i was considered a radical
i'll never forget the day i was called in by a member of top management and told to stop associating with any known or suspected environmentalists
chris i had no intention of of doing that
and i kept speaking out about the environment
and it really was the topic that we now today call sustainability
and in time, my views went from controversy o two more less consensus today
i mean, i think most people in the industry understand that we've got to get on with it
and the good news is today we are tackling the big issues, of of cars and the environment, not only for, the really as an industry
we're pushing fuel efficiency to new heights
there was no technology, we're reducing, and i believe, someday we'll eliminate, CO two emissions
we're starting to sell electric cars, which is great
we're developing alternative powertrains that are going to make the our cars affordable in every sense of the word, economically, socially and environmentally
and actually, although we've got a long way to go and a lot of work to do, i can see the day when my two great passions, cars and the environment, actually come into harmony

but unfortunately, as were our way to solving one monstrous problem, and as i said, we're not there yet. we've got a lot of work to do, but i can see where we will, but it even as we're in the process of doing that, another huge problem is looming, and people are noticing
and that is the freedom of mobility that my great grandfather brought to people is now being threatened just as the environment is
the problem, put in its simplest terms, is one of mathematics
today there are approximately six point eight billion people in the world
and within our lifetime, that number's going to grow to about nine billion
in it that population level, our planet will be dealing with the limits of growth
and with that growth comes some severe practical problems, one of which is our transportation system simply won't be able to deal with that
when we look at the population growth in terms of cars, it becomes even clearer
today there are about eight hundred million cars on the road worldwide
and but with more people and greater prosperity around the world, that number's going to grow to between two and four billion cars by mid-century
and this is going to create the kind of global gridlock that the world is never seen before
let's think about the impact that this is going to have our daily lives
today the average american spends about a week a year stuck in traffic jams
and that's a huge waste of time and resources
but that's nothing compared to what's going on in the nations that are growing the fastest
today the average driver in beijing has a five hour commute
and last summer, many of you probably saw this, there was a hundred mile traffic jam that took eleven days to clear in china
in the decades to come, seventy five percent of the world's population will live in cities, and fifty of those cities will be of ten million people or more
so you can see the size of the issue that we're facing
when you factor in population growth, it's clear that the mobility model that we have today simply will not work tomorrow
frankly, four billion clean cars on the road are still four billion cars
and a traffic jam with no emissions is still a traffic jam
so health, if we make no changes today, what tomorrow look like?
like think you probably already have the picture
traffic jams are just a symptom of this challenge, and they're really very, very inconvenient, but that's kind of all they are
but the bigger issue is that global gridlock is going to stifle economic growth and our ability to deliver food and health care, particularly to people that live in city centres
and our quality of life is going to be severely compromised
so what's going to solve this?
well the answer isn't going to be more of the same

my great grandfather once said before he invented the model t, if i ask people than what they wanted, they would have answered, we want faster forces. so the answer to more cars is simply not to have more roads
what america began moving west, we can add more wagon trains, we built railroads
and to connect our country after world war two, we didn't build more two-lane highways, we built the interstate highway system
today we need that same leap and thinking for us to create a viable future
we are going to build smart cars, but we also need to build smart roads, smart parking, smart public transportation systems and more
we don't want to waste their time sitting in traffic, sitting at all those or looking for parking spots
we need an integrated system that uses real-time data to optimize personal mobility on a massive scale without hassle or compromises for travelers
if i could have the kind of system that's going to make the future of of personal mobility sustainable
now the good news is some of this work is already begun in different parts of the world
the city of mass star in upper darby uses driverless electric vehicles that can communicate with one another, and they go underneath the city streets
up above, you've got a series of pedestrian walkways
a new york city's thirty four street, gridlock will soon be replaced with a connected system of vehicle specific orders

pedestrian zones in dedicated traffic lanes are going to be created, and all of this will look cut down the average rush hour commute to get across town in new york from about an hour today at rush hour to about twenty minutes
now if you look at hong kong, they have a very interesting system paul arctic was there
it's a system that really ties together all the transportation assets into a single payment system
so parking garages, buses, trains, they all operate within the same system
now shared power services are also springing up around the world
and these efforts, i think are great
the relieving congestion, and they're frankly starting to save some fuel
these are all really good ideas that will move us forward
but what really inspires me is what's really possible what our cars can begin talking to each other
very soon, the same system that we use today to bring music and in entertainment and GPS information into our vehicles are going to be used to create a smart vehicle network
every morning i drive about thirty miles from my home in ann arbor to my office and you're one, michigan
and every night i go home, my commute is a total crapshoot
and i often have to leave the freeway and look for different ways for me to try and make it home
but very soon we're going to see the days when cars are essentially talking to each other
so if the car ahead of me and i ninety four hits traffic, it will immediately alert my car and tell my car to reroute itself to get me home in the best possible way
and these systems are being tested right now, and frankly they're going to be ready for prime time pretty soon
but the potential of a connected car network is almost live limitless
one day very soon, you'll be able to plan a trip downtown in your car will be connected to a smart parking system

so you get your car, and as you get in your car, your car will reserve you parking spot before you arrive, no more driving around looking for one, which frankly is one of the biggest users of fuel in today's cars and in urban areas is looking for parking spots
or think about being in new york city and tracking down an intelligent cab on your smartphone so you don't have to wait and the cold to hail one

or being in the future ted conference and having your car talk to the calendars of everybody here and telling you all the best route to take home and when you should leave, so the goal arriving here next destination on time
this is the kind of technology that will merge millions of individual vehicles into a single system
so i think it's clear we have the beginnings of a solution to this enormous problem
but as we found out with addressing CO two issues, and also fossil fuels, there is no one silver bullet
the solution is not going to be more cars, more roads or new rail system. it can only be found, i believe, in a global network of interconnected solutions

now i know we can develop the technology that's going to make this work, we gotta be willing to get out there and seek out the solutions, whether that means vehicle sharing or public transportation or some other way we haven't even thought of yet, our overall transportation mix an infrastructure must support all the future options
we need our best and our brightest to start entertaining this issue
companies, entrepreneurs, venture capitalists, they all need to understand this is a huge business opportunity, is well as an enormous social problem

and just as these groups embrace the green energy challenge, and i was really been amazing to me to watch how much brain power, how much money and how much serious thought isn't, it over the last three, really three years is poured into the green energy field
we need that same kind of passion and energy to attack global gridlock
we need people like all of you in this room, leading thinkers
and frankly i really need all of you to think about how you can help solve this this huge issue
and we need people from all walks of life. not just inventors, we need policymakers in government officials to also think about how they're going to respond to this challenge
this is going to be solved by any one person or one group

it's going to really require a national energy policy of frankly for each country, because the solutions in each country are going to be different based upon income levels, traffic jams and also how integrated the the systems already are
but we need to get going, and we need to get going today
and we must have an infrastructure that's designed to support this flexible future
you know, we've come a long way
since the model t, most people never traveled more than twenty five miles from home and their entire lifetime
and since then, but the automobile has allowed us the freedom to choose where we live, where we work, where we play and frankly when we just go out and want to move around
we don't want to regress we lose that freedom

we're on our way to solving, and as i said earlier, i know that a long way to go, the one big issue that we're all focused on that threatens it, and that's the environmental issue, but i believe we all must turn all over africa and all over ingenuity and determination to help now solve this notion of global gridlock
because in doing so, we're going to preserve what we've really come to take for granted, which is the freedom to move and move very effortlessly around the world
and and and frankly will enhance our quality of life if we fix this

because, if you can envision, as i do, a future of zero emissions in freedom to move around the country and around the world like we take for granted today, that's worth of hard work today to preserve that for tomorrow
i believe we're at our best when we're confronted with the issues
this is a big one and it won't wait
so let's get started now
thank you

doc.description: New York was planning to tear down the High Line, an abandoned elevated railroad in Manhattan, when Robert Hammond and a few friends suggested: Why not make it a park? He shares how it happened in this tale of local cultural activism.
doc.title: Robert Hammond: Building a park in the sky
doc.seg: the high line is an old, elevated rail line that runs for a mile and a half right through manhattan
and it was originally a freight line that ran down ten thousand
and it became known as death avenue because so many people were run over by the trains that the railroad hired a guy in first back to run in front, and he became known as the west side cowboy
but even with a cowboy, about one person in a month was killed and run over
so the elevated it
they built a thirty feet, in the air right through the middle of the city
but with the rise of interstate trucking, it was used a less and less
and by nineteen eighty the last train rode
it was a train motor frozen turkeys, they say, at thanksgiving, from the meatpacking district
and that it was abandoned
and i live in the neighborhood, and i first read about it in the new york times, in articles that it said it was going to be demolished
and i assume someone was working to preserve it or save it i volunteer, but i realized no one was doing anything
i would my first community board meeting, which i'd never been to one before, and sat next to another guy named joshua david, was a travel writer
and at the end of the meeting, we realize we're the only two people there were so interest in the project. was people wanted to tear it down
so we exchanged business cards, and we kept calling each other and decided to start this organisation, friends of the high line
and the goal at first was just saving it from demolition, but then we also wanted to figure out what we could do with it
and what first attracted me, are interested me, with this this view from the street, which is this you know steel structure, was a rusty, this industrial relic

but when i went up on top, it was a mile and a half of wildflowers running right through the middle of manhattan you know with views of the empire state building and the statue of liberty and had some river
and that's really where we started, the idea of coalesced around, let's make this a park, and let's have it be sort of inspired by this a wild skate
at the time, there was a lot of opposition
mayor giuliani wanted to tear it down
i'm a fast forward to a lot of lawsuits and a lot of sort of community engagement
mayor bloomberg came in office, he was very supportive, but we still have to make the economic case
this was after nine allowed in. the city was in tough times
so we commissioned an economic feasibility study to try to make the case
and it turns out, we got those numbers wrong
we said it would cost a hundred million dollars to build
so far it's cost about a hundred and fifty million
and the the main case was, this is going to make good economic sense for the city
so we said over twenty year time period, the value to the city and increased property values and increased taxes would be about two hundred fifty million
that was enough. it really got the city behind it
it turns out we were wrong on that
now people estimate it's created about has a billion dollars, and will create about half a billion dollars, in tax revenues for the city
we did a design competition, selected the design team
we worked with them to really create a design that was inspired by that sort of wild skate
there's three sections
we open the first section in two thousand nine
it's been so successful beyond our dreams
last year we had about two million people, which is about ten times what we ever estimated
this is one of my favorite features in section one
it's this amphitheater right over ten thousand
on the first section in the twentieth street right now
the other thing, it's generated, obviously, a lot of economic value. it's also inspired, i think, a lot of great architecture is
there's a point, where you can stand here and see buildings by frank gehry, jean new bell, sugar bond, yields and ari
and the whitney is moving downtown and is building that their new museum right at the base of the high line
in this is being designed by renzo piano
and they're going to break ground in may
and we've already started construction on section two
this is one of my favorite features, this flyover where year eight feet off the surface of the high line, running through a canopy of trees
the high line used to be covered in billboards, and so we've sort of taken a playful take where instead of framing advertising, and it's because frame people and views of the city
this was just installed last month
and then the last section it was going to go around the rail yards, which is the largest undeveloped site in manhattan
and the city has planned, for better for worse, at twelve million square feet of development the line is going to ring around
but you know, what really, i think, makes the high line special is the people

and honestly, even though i love the designs that we're building, i was always frightened that i wouldn't really love it, because i fell love without wild escape, and how could you re-create that magic?
but what i found is it is it's in the people and how they use it that, to me, makes it so special
just one quick example is i realize right after we opened that they're all these people holding hands on the high line
i realized new yorkers don't hold his that. we just don't do that and outside fate
well you see that happening on the high line, and i think that's you know the power that the public space can have to transform how people experience the city and interact with each other
thank you for

doc.description: Is there something you've always meant to do, wanted to do, but just ... haven't? Matt Cutts suggests: Try it for 30 days. This short, lighthearted talk offers a neat way to think about setting and achieving goals.
doc.title: Matt Cutts: Try something new for 30 days
doc.seg: a few years ago, i felt like i was stuck in a rut, so i decided to follow in the footsteps of the great american philosopher, morgan spurlock, and try something new for thirty days
the idea is actually pretty simple
think about something you've always wanted to add to your life and try it for the next thirty days
it turns out, thirty days is just about the right amount of time to have new habit or subtract a habit, like watching the news, from your life
there's a few things that i learned while doing these thirty day challenges
the first was, instead of the months flying by, forgotten, the time was much more memorable
this was part of a challenge i did to take a picture every day for a month
and i remember exactly where i was and what i was doing that day
i also noticed that as i started to do more and harder thirty day challenges, my self-confidence grew
i went from death dwelling computer nerd to the kind of guy who bikes to work, for fun
even last year, i ended up hiking up mount kilimanjaro, the highest mountain in africa
i would never have been dead adventurous before i started my thirty day challenges
i also figured out that if you really want something badly enough, you can do anything for thirty days
if you're wanted write a novel?
every november, tens of thousands of people try to write their own fifty thousand word novel from scratch in thirty days
it turns out, all you have to do is write sixteen hundred and sixty seven words a day for a month
so i did
by the way, the secret is not to go to sleep and so you've written your words for the day
you might be sleep-deprived, but you'll finish a novel
now is my book the next great american novel?
now all i wrote in a month
it's cool
but for the rest of my life, if i meet john hodge and meditate party, i don't have to say, i'm a computer scientist
now, now, if i want to i can say, i'm a novelist
so here's one last thing i'd like to mention
i learned that when i made small, sustainable changes, things i could keep doing, they're more likely to stick
there's nothing wrong with big, crazy challenges
in fact, there a ton of fun
but they're less likely to stick
when i gave up sugar for thirty days, day thirty one looked like this
so here's my question to you, what do you waiting for?
i guarantee you the next thirty days are going to pass whether you like it or not, so why not think about something you've always wanted to try and give it a shot for the next thirty days
thanks

doc.description: Tissue engineer and TED Fellow Nina Tandon is growing artificial hearts and bones. To do that, she needs new ways of caring for artificially grown cells -- techniques she's developed by the simple but powerful method of copying their natural environments.
doc.title: Nina Tandon: Caring for engineered tissue
doc.seg: good morning everybody
i work with really amazing that will itty-bitty creatures called cells
and let me tell you what it's like to grow these cells in the lab
i work in the lab where we take cells out of their native environment
we played them into dishes that we sometimes call petri dishes
and we feed them, stay early of course, with what we call cell culture media, which is like their food and we grow them in incubators
why do i do this?
we observe the cells in a plate, and there know just on the surface
but what we're really trying to do in my lab is to engineer tissues out of that
what does that even mean?
well it means growing in actual heart, let's say, or grow a piece of bone that can be put into the body
not only that, but they can also be used for disease models
i'm going to purpose, traditional cell culture techniques just really aren't enough
the cells are kind of homesick. the dish doesn't feel like their home
and so we need to do better at copying their natural environment to get them to thrive
we call this the by in the medical paradigm, copying nature in the lab
let's take the example of the heart, the topic of a lot of my research
what makes the heart unique?
well, the heart beats rhythmically, tirelessly, faithfully
we copy this in the land by outfitting cell culture systems with electrodes
these electrodes act like mini pacemakers to get the cells contract in the lab
what else do we know about the heart?
well heart cells are pretty greedy
nature feeds the heart cells in your body with a very, very dense blood supply
in the lab, we might for patterns channels in the by materials on which we grow the cells
and this allows us to flow the cell culture media, the cells food, through the scaffolds were growing the cells, a lot like what you might expect from a cap larry capillary bed in the heart
so this brings me to lesson number one, life can do a lot with very little
let's take the example of electrical stimulation
let's see how powerful just one of these essentials can be
on the left, we see a tiny piece of beating heart tissue that they engineered from rat cells in the lab
it's about the size of a mini marshmallow
after one week, it's beating
you can see it up in the upper left-hand corner
the door if you can see it so well
it's amazing that these cells beat at all

that brings me to lesson number jim, cells do all the work

in a sense, tissue engineers have a bit of an identity crisis here, because, you know, a structural engineers build bridges and big things, computer engineers, computers, but what we are doing is actually building enabling technologies for the cells themselves
what is this mean for us?
let's do something really simple
let's remind ourselves that cells are not an abstract concept
let's remember that our cells sustain our lives in a very real way
we are what we eat, could easily be described as, we are what our cells eat
and in the case of the flora in our gut, these cells may not even be human
but it's also worth noting that cells also mediate our experience of life
behind every sound, sight, touch, taste and smell is a corresponding set of cells that receive this information and interpret it for us
it begs the question, cell we expand our sense of environmental stewardship to include the ecosystem of our own bodies?
